feed.title: NewsTracker: apple or microsoft
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Microsoft plans major job cuts: NYT
entry.summary:
Microsoft Corp, the world's largest software company, plans to announce a new round of layoffs as early as Wednesday as it tries to cut costs further, the New York Times reported.

The latest job cuts are in addition to the 18,000 jobs Microsoft said it planned to cut a year ago, the newspaper said, citing sources familiar with the matter.

The layoffs are expected to affect employees at the hardware group and other parts of the company, including the smartphone business that Microsoft acquired from Nokia last year, the newspaper said.

entry.title: Taylor Swift: 'I've decided to put 1989 on Apple Music ... and happily so'
entry.summary:
Taylor Swift's album "1989" will be available on Apple's new music service, following the company's reversal of a controversial policy on royalties.

"After the events of this week, I've decided to put 1989 on Apple Music ... and happily so," Swift said on Twitter.

Apple Music doesn't offer a free tier.

Apple Music charges $9.99 a month for its Spotify-like service, which launches Tuesday.

Apple has promised to pay rights holders at least 71.5 percent of its streaming revenue when customers pay the $9.99 a month subscription.

entry.title: Dr. Dre announces new radio show on Apple Music service
entry.summary:
Apple bought Dre and Jimmy Iovine's Beats by Dre company last year.

Apple's new streaming service features live radio programming, including shows hosted by Zane Lowe, Ebro Darden and Julie Adenuga.

entry.title: Dr. Dre announces new radio show on Apple Music service
entry.summary: Dr. Dre will be busting through your speakers with a new radio show on Apple Music.

entry.title: Apple Music promises revolution, but traditional DJs are what set it apart
entry.summary:
Real-time radio, of all things, is what truly distinguishes the newest and splashiest streaming service, Apple Music.

Apple has about 30 million songs to stream at your request.

Complete with high-profile DJs and programmed shows, it sets the service apart from the pack and best illustrates Apple's ambition - to become a destination spot not unlike media giants of yore.

entry.title: Spotify Raises $526 Million in Apple Battle
US court agrees Apple violated antitrust law in e-book entry
entry.summary:
In a statement, Apple said the ruling did nothing to change the fact that it did not conspire to fix e-book pricing.

In the majority opinion, though, Livingston said it was "startling" that Jacobs would agree Apple intentionally organized a conspiracy among publishers to raise e-book prices and then say the company was entitled to do so because the conspiracy helped it become an e-book retailer.

entry.title: Appeals court agrees Apple violated antitrust law in e-books case
entry.summary: Two publishers joined Apple's appeal.

entry.title: Apple conspired to fix e-book prices: U.S. appeals court
entry.summary: "While we want to put this behind us, the case is about principles and values," Apple said in a statement.

entry.title: Apple conspired to fix e-book prices: U.S. appeals court
entry.summary: A divided federal appeals court on Tuesday said Apple Inc. orchestrated a conspiracy with five publishers to increase e-book prices, in a victory for the U.S. Justice Department.

entry.title: US court agrees Apple violated antitrust law in e-book entry
entry.summary: The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Manhattan ruled 2-to-1 Tuesday that a lower court judge was right to find Apple violated the laws to upset Amazon.com's control of the market.

Microsoft hands display ads to AOL, maps to Uber
Microsoft sheds some of its ad business, mapping service
entry.summary: Microsoft is handing off some its digital advertising business to AOL and selling its street-image mapping operation to Uber, as the giant software company tries to focus on activities more relevant to its core business.

entry.title: Microsoft sheds some of its ad business, mapping service
entry.summary: An AOL Inc. spokeswoman said the New York-based online media company will extend job offers to all 1,200 people who worked in Microsoft's advertising business.

entry.title: Microsoft sheds some of its ad business, mapping service
entry.summary:
AOL, meanwhile, is adopting Microsoft's Bing search engine, replacing Google as the default option for visitors who want to search the Internet on AOL websites.

That means Microsoft will get a share of revenue from advertising that's tied directly to Internet searches performed on AOL.

Under its agreement with AOL, Microsoft is unloading a business that's declined in importance over recent years.

Both companies characterized the deal as a win-win because Microsoft will gain more search advertising while AOL, which has been beefing up its display business, will now add Microsoft's websites to a host of other online properties where AOL can place messages for advertising clients.

entry.title: Microsoft Corp reveals gigantic US$20,000 84-inch Surface Hub designed for conferencing
entry.summary:
It will run a custom version of Windows 10, Microsoft's new operating system due out in late July.

Microsoft unveiled a prototype of the new device in January.

entry.title: Apple removing games with Confederate flag from App Store
entry.summary: Apple Inc., which is based in Cupertino, California, is the latest company to distance itself from the divisive symbol after the shooting suspect, Dylann Storm Roof, appeared in photos holding the flag.

entry.title: Apple pulls Confederate flag-bearing Civil War games from App Store
entry.summary: Apple issued the following statement: "We have removed apps from the App Store that use the Confederate flag in offensive or mean-spirited ways, which is in violation of our guidelines. We are not removing apps that display the Confederate flag for educational or historical uses."

entry.title: Apple bans Civil War games featuring Confederate flag from App store
entry.summary: The move by Apple prompted some criticism from users online, concerned the ban was ignoring the context in which the symbol was used in some cases and pointing out that World War II games featuring Nazi insignia were still being sold from the store.

entry.title: Apple removes games featuring Confederate flags from App Store
entry.summary:
Apple Inc has removed several civil war games featuring Confederate flags from its App Store, some game developers said.

"Apple has removed our game from AppStore because of usage of the Confederate Flag," Game-Labs, developer of Ultimate General: Gettysburg said.

entry.title: Record industry warily embraces Apple Music
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO - A decade ago, Apple Inc. helped revitalize a music industry hit hard by online piracy with its iTunes Store.

But despite the generally positive reaction to Apple's announcement, some music companies are still concerned because of the tough economics of the streaming business, said Sherman.

If Apple is successful, said Ted Cohen, a former music executive, others in the industry may decide to weaken or phase out their free tiers, he added.

"Apple Music is more of a me-too product than a breakthrough product," he said.

entry.title: Taylor Swift Explains Why '1989' Won't Be on Apple Music in Open Letter
entry.summary: "I'm not sure you know that Apple Music will not be paying writers, producers, or artists for those three months. I find it to be shocking, disappointing, and completely unlike this historically progressive and generous company."

entry.title: Apple?s bag-search policy treats workers as ?criminals': suit

Cook's response to that email is not displayed in the court filing, though other Apple executives did discuss the bag search policy.

Apple puts news at core of revamped system
entry.summary:
Washington: Apple is diving deeper into the news business with a new application that could make the US tech giant a key industry player.

"Apple is eager to have news created by human beings and not algorithms - it fits in with the brand statement Apple has been making," said Judd Slivka, a professor of mobile journalism at the University of Missouri.

entry.title: Apple puts news at core of revamped system
entry.summary: In a surprising move, Apple has unveiled it will be hiring experienced journalists to manage its news feeds.

entry.title: Nokia Theatre, home of the Emmys, renamed Microsoft Theater
entry.summary:
LOS ANGELES (AP) - Los Angeles' Nokia Theatre will now be known as the Microsoft Theater.

Microsoft and theater owner AEG announced Tuesday that the 7,100-seat venue is being rebranded.

The 40,000-square-foot plaza outside the theater will similarly be known as Microsoft Square, and the nearby 3,100-seat venue Club Nokia will also be rebranded.

entry.title: Apple puts news at core of revamped system
entry.summary:
Apple News, part of the upcoming iOS 9 operating system, aims to be the primary news source for users of the iPhone and iPad.

Customers browse Apple Watches in New York.

Although Apple is likely to use some algorithms to filter stories, the hiring of experienced journalists is a positive step, said Dan Kennedy, a journalism professor at Northeastern University.

Partner news organisations include Conde Nast magazines, ESPN, The New York Times, Hearst, Time Inc., CNN and Bloomberg, but Apple will be opening to other publishers and bloggers.

entry.title: In with the old: Apple restores former bank for new store
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - To create the newest Apple store to sell iPhones, smartwatches and other modern gadgetry, Apple took a look back at the 1920s.

It's all part of Apple's effort to keep its stores distinct - not just from other retailers but from each other.

And as Apple looks to open new stores or renovate existing ones - including the iconic New York Fifth Avenue store, with its distinctive glass-cube entrance - the company will look for additional ways to do that.

entry.title: In with the old: Apple restores former bank for new store
entry.summary:
Apple has generic stores, too, such as ones in shopping malls.

Upper East Side will be Apple's 266th store in the U.S. and seventh in New York City, a key market for Apple because it gets twice as much traffic as stores in other U.S. cities.

As Apple opens new stores, it will also renovate about 20 existing U.S. stores, including the ones on Fifth Avenue and San Francisco's Union Square.

The Latest from Apple show: Siri to be a better assistant
entry.summary: Apple isn't saying anything ahead of time, though it's widely expected the company will unveil updates to its mobile and Mac operating systems, along with a new music service.

entry.title: Latest from Apple's WWDC: Mac update called 'El Capitan'
entry.summary:
Apple says this fall's update to its Mac operating system will be called El Capitan -- the name of a landmark in Yosemite National Park.

It follows a recent practice of Apple naming the Mac operating system after geographical locations in California.

The new Mac system will be more formally known as OS X 10.11, as it's the 11th update to a system adapted from the NeXT operating system that co-founder Steve Jobs brought to Apple when he returned in 1997 after an exile.

The Worldwide Developers Conference in San Francisco is Apple's chance to preview software updates for Macs, iPhones, iPads and the Apple Watch.

It's similar to Apple's Worldwide Developers Conference in that it gives Google the stage for showcasing upcoming features and products.

entry.title: Apple set to unveil new music streaming service

entry.title: Apple wants a lead role in streaming music
entry.summary: Along with a new music service, industry experts had been expecting Apple to announce a new streaming-video package and upgrades for its Apple TV service.

entry.title: Apple wants a lead role in streaming music
entry.summary: Apple is expected to announce its new paid streaming-music service at its annual conference for software developers, which kicks off Monday, June 8, 2015.

entry.title:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Apple's iTunes helped change the way music-lovers bought their favorite songs, replacing plastic discs with digital downloads.

In a keynote session, CEO Tim Cook and other executives are also expected to show off new features in Apple's operating software for iPhones, iPads and Macintosh computers, as well as tools for building new apps for the Apple Watch.

But Apple uses its annual World Wide Developers Conference to highlight the software, online services and apps that make those devices indispensable to consumers around the world.

That puts the spotlight on Apple's music initiative.
